hobby.message: Political literature age better than policy?
You still tuning those antique typewriters?
What's your last origami fold say?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Enough time for paperwork. Sometimes I restore typewriters. Not much use lately.
No real trouble getting here. I keep busy with small things, that's all.
Not far. Gave me a moment for my old typewriter—keeps my hands steady.
Restoring it helps me pass the time.
Score changes lately made it harder, but I manage.
Just a short walk. Had time to clean up an Olympia today—typewriters are my hobby.
Restoring the mechanics, realigning the keys, it’s calming.
When scores leveled, I actually typed beside my window.
Usually it’s pen and paper... these days, it’s safer.
Not so long. Gave me a rare stretch to work on my old Olympia SM9.
Typewriter restoration—an odd habit, I know.
Used to be my way to get off the grid.
When the scores leveled out—well, I tried typing a page like old times.
Didn’t last, security came back fast.
Still, it felt possible for a while.
Walk was short for once. Scored equalization let me use spaces normally off limits.
Typewriter restoration is my quiet rebellion—Olympias, Remingtons, whatever survives.
For one morning, I typed openly in the common room. No audit alarms for hours.
Restoring the click and rhythm, you know, it’s a memory trick too.
I keep a handwritten journal now—can't trust the system not to watch digital notes.
When Directorate reinstated the old scores, I packed everything up fast.
Security’s always watching again. Old habits return.
Still—those six hours, it was almost like before Halden built the BCI.
hobby_answer: Yes. Still collecting.
Just one or two, nothing special.
Had them since before everything got... digitized.
No trouble last week. I keep to myself.
Was a quiet hobby until all the excitement with access changes.
Yes, I still collect typewriters.
They’re mostly packed away these days.
Only use them when things are calm.
You saw the equalization, right? Briefly made it easier to bring one out.
Didn’t last. Back to routines now.
No sense drawing attention with old machines.
I do, still collecting typewriters whenever I find one intact.
Restored an Olympia last month. Needed new ribbon, surprisingly easy to find then.
During the score leveling, I could actually set up in the lounge.
Normally not possible for me. Access rules, you know.
Felt like stepping back in time—no silent sensors watching every move.
That was brief, of course. Back to lock and badge now.
Still, for a morning, I typed like old days.
Yes, still at it—collecting, fixing, anything mechanical from before the system took over.
You know I prefer to type, not tap.
With the score equalization, I finally set up in the community room.
Everyone mingled. I typed, nobody cared. No badge to flash, no reports.
It reminded me how it felt before everything was tracked, sorted.
For a while, I let the Olympia clatter as loud as I liked.
But it snapped back so fast—Directorate’s hand, as always.
Afterwards, I hid the machine away. I’m careful who sees it now.
Absolutely, still collecting—can’t kill old habits, even as the city changes.
I used to run Council memos on these—less risk of silent edits.
When they leveled our scores, I set up in the open for hours.
First time in years—felt like the place belonged to people, not the system.
Neighbors gathered, curious. Some had never heard a typewriter in real life.
Children asked if it was a music box. Imagine that.
But the Directorate shut the door on it—list went up, my name back on it.
Leniency gone, suspicion returns. Typewriter’s hidden again.
Funny. Under all this tech, paper still feels honest.
